context: <b5_0>A government report<b5_0/> covered by <a0_0>the Guardian<a0_0/> in 2002 indicates that <a3_0>between 1940 and 1979<a3_0/>, the Ministry of Defence "<b6_0>turned large parts of the country into a giant laboratory<b6_0/> <b7_0>to conduct a series of <a1_0>secret germ warfare tests<b7_0/><a1_0/> on the public" and many of these tests "involved releasing potentially dangerous chemicals and micro-organisms over vast swaths of the population without the public being told." The Ministry of Defence claims that these trials were to simulate germ warfare and that <b8_0>the tests were harmless<b8_0/>. Still, families who have been in the area of many of the tests are experiencing <a2_0>children with birth defects and physical and mental handicaps<a2_0/> and many are asking for <b9_0>a public inquiry<b9_0/>. According to the report these tests affected estimated millions of people including one period <a4_0>between 1961 and 1968<a4_0/> where "more than a million people along the south coast of England, from Torquay to the New Forest, were exposed to bacteria including e.coli and bacillus globigii, which mimics anthrax."
